name: Osaka
fun_fact: Fun fact: Osaka is called 'Tenka no Daidokoro' (Japan's Kitchen) and almost every household owns a takoyaki maker! The city developed a unique 'konamon' culture centered on flour-based street foods.

hero_dishes.name: Takoyaki
hero_dishes.description: Crispy-on-the-outside, molten-on-the-inside octopus balls made from flour and egg batter with octopus chunks, pickled ginger, and green onion, topped with takoyaki sauce, mayo, aonori (green laver), and katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes)
hero_dishes.origin_story: The king of Osaka street food, takoyaki literally means 'grilled octopus.' Cooked in special takoyaki pans that mold the batter into perfect spheres, these generate absurdly long lines at Dotonbori stalls and have become emblematic of Osaka's street food scene.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Takoyaki Wanaka (famous for perfectly crispy texture), Aizuya (one of the original vendors serving simple sauce-free version), Kukuru (known for large, chewy octopus pieces with melt-in-your-mouth batter). Found throughout Dotonbori and Tenjinbashi-suji Shopping Street. Typically 300-800 yen per serving (6-12 pieces).

hero_dishes.name: Okonomiyaki
hero_dishes.description: Savory pancake-like dish where shredded cabbage and ingredients like squid, prawn, octopus, or meat are mixed into flour-based batter and grilled, then topped with okonomiyaki sauce, mayo, aonori, and katsuobushi
hero_dishes.origin_story: The method of 'mixing flour and frying' was devised by Sen no Rikyu, a prominent tea master active in the 1500s. Osaka-style okonomiyaki mixes all ingredients together before cooking, unlike Hiroshima's layered style. Some restaurants let customers prepare it themselves on table hot plates.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Kiji in Umeda (serves authentic, fluffy okonomiyaki), Ajinoya (humble joint rated highly by Michelin for savory Japanese pancakes). Found throughout Dotonbori and Shinsekai districts. Typically 800-1,500 yen depending on toppings.

hero_dishes.name: Kushikatsu
hero_dishes.description: Deep-fried skewered meat, seafood, and vegetables served with a communal dipping sauce (strict no double-dipping rule!)
hero_dishes.origin_story: Part of Osaka's 'konamon' (flour-based) food culture that defines the city's cuisine. Especially popular in Shinsekai district.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Shinsekai district is the kushikatsu capital. Tenjinbashi-suji Shopping Street (Japan's longest at 2.6 km) has many vendors.

signature_drinks.name: Local Beer and Highballs
signature_drinks.description: Japanese beer and whisky highballs pair perfectly with Osaka's rich street food
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed standing at street food stalls or sitting at outdoor tables along Dotonbori canal while watching the neon lights and crowds

food_culture_notes: Osaka is known as 'Japan's Kitchen' due to its exceptional culinary scene and affordable, delicious food
Konamon culture: dishes made with wheat flour are deeply rooted in daily life (takoyaki, okonomiyaki, kushikatsu)
Dotonbori is the most famous food district with neon lights, giant billboards (iconic Glico running man sign), and countless street vendors
Kuromon Ichiba Market offers fresh seafood and local produce
Tenjinbashi-suji is Japan's longest shopping street (2.6 km) with all Osaka gourmet foods gathered in one place
Osakans are proud of being 'the city with the friendliest and funniest people in Japan'
Kansai-ben dialect is lively and direct, often associated with comedy (many famous comedians hail from the region)

landmarks: Osaka Castle - 1583 castle with ferro-concrete tower rebuilt in 1931, beautifully illuminated at night
Dotonbori canal with iconic Glico running man billboard and eccentric neon signboards
Cherry blossoms at Nishinomaru Garden (former western citadel of Osaka Castle)
atmosphere: Bustling nightlife and entertainment in Dotonbori's neon-lit streets
Street food vendors with long lines of loyal customers
Theater district heritage (Dotonbori was historically a theater district, birthplace of Bunraku puppet theater)
Lively, direct communication style with Kansai-ben dialect
Friendly, funny locals who are proud of their city and food culture
colors: Bright neon reds, yellows, and blues from Dotonbori signboards
White and gold of illuminated Osaka Castle at night
Golden-brown of crispy takoyaki and okonomiyaki
Pink cherry blossoms in spring at castle park
unique_modern: Giant 3D billboards and mechanical crab signs on Dotonbori buildings
Takoyaki pans in nearly every household
Interactive dining where customers cook okonomiyaki at table hot plates
Street food culture meets modern urban nightlife
